utterances: First of all, just how new is this government and how unified do you think it is?
Well many of these faces have been seen before in previous iterations of Iraqi governments.
But the prime minister is new, several cabinets members are new.
The biggest chance, of course, a much greater number of Sunni politicians from an alliance known as Tuwafuk(ph).
That alliance took the majority of votes in the Sunni dominated areas last December.
There's a smaller Sunni group we should note, led by a man named Sallah Mutlock(ph), which is refusing to join.
He gave an angry speech and several Sunnis walked out today.
But the voting went on despite that.
As for how unified this government is, that's very much still a question.
There's a balancing act going on among the Kurdish, Shiite and Sunni parties and also between religious and secular elements in the Arab groups.
U.S.
officials have already hailed this government as a major blow against the insurgency just by being formed, but nobody thinks the insurgents are packing up just yet.
Sadly, and I suppose, not surprisingly, the new government was greeted with more killing today.
What happened?
Well, the worst blast hit in the poor Sadr City neighborhood of Baghdad, a largely Shiite spot, where day laborers gather looking for work, a target that we've seen in the past.
Also a suicide bombing in Kaam(ph), a rebellious city near the Syrian border, destroying a police station.
And many more bodies were also found, as they are almost every day, shot execution style, some showing signs of torture.
Peter, every interim, provisional, temporary government to date has put security at the top of its agenda and there's been almost no discernible effect.
Does this government, with its four-year term, really have something new to offer to solve the problem?
Well, we're not going to find out right away, unfortunately for some.
If today's address by Mr. Maliki is any indication, he's going to take a month to unveil his detailed program of governance.
That's on top of this five-month delay we've just had.
Obviously, his first week will be taken up trying to get permanent seats, permanent people in the defense and interior ministry seats.
He's trying to avoid people with close ties to sectarian or ethnic militias and then we will see if he's serious about trying to integrate those militias into other jobs.
What about priorities beyond security?
Using the AlphaSmart and WordPerfect, I've started to enjoy computing again.
There's no Wikipedia, no e-mail, no constantly changing the MP3s I'm listening to, no downloading going on.
Yeah?
Generally, the - a lot of apprehension, a lot of worried people, we have literally, hundreds of fires burning as a result of the lightning strikes.
Everybody is doing their best.
The people in Northern California are very independent, and they are appreciative of the help.
And, as you know, the help that we supply to the American Red Cross, is provided by a very generous American public.
Mm-hm.
And I just like to thank everybody that's listening for further generosity.
And tell us about the weather.
You mentioned earlier that the electrical storms caused this about a week ago.
The weather, not expected to improve this weekend?
Well, the weather is not expected to improve.
As a matter of fact, there is concern about a high-level condition that is conducive to providing - or producing more lightning.
So, we are taking action to put some standby shelters on the list to - in case we get more of the same, but right now, it's very, very, hazy, and the sky is clear, but...
You're on alert.
You expect to change by this weekend.
You're on alert.
Well, how many people do you expect, will seek shelter?
It's very hard.
Right now, the potential for sheltering is in the thousands.
But rarely does it worked out that way, because most of the people visit their friends, and relatives, and what have you.
But it could be hundreds more.
Hundreds more people.
And we're making provisions for thousands more.
So, we have all of our volunteers lined up, and ready to go should that be necessary.
Bob Ganiard is with the American Red Cross, based in Sacramento - or north of Sacrament in Yuba City.
Bob Ganiard, thank you very much.
Thank you for having me.
(Soundbite of music)
Stay with us.
Marketplace is next, when Day to Day continues.
This Thursday, February 14, marks one year since the mass shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla.
Seventeen people were killed that day.
A few weeks after the shooting, NPR's Melissa Block profiled the family of one of the Parkland victims.
Her name was Carmen Schentrup.
She was a senior.
Now Melissa visits the family again to talk about their year of grief, anger and activism.
The days now go something like this.
(SOUNDBITE OF ZIPPER CLOSING)
All right.
Let's go.
Dad Philip Schentrup heads to the office.
On his backpack, there's a small blue pin, a tribute made by a friend.
It shows Carmen's smiling face and a message.
Be the change.
Carmen Schentrup.
Do you like having that on there?
Absolutely.
And I don't think it's ever coming off.
A few miles away...
UNIDENTIFIED PERSON #1: Come in, April.
Sit wherever you want.
...Mom April Schentrup seeks comfort at a grief support group.
That feeling, like, other people have moved on and it's hard for us to get there.
And back at home...
UNIDENTIFIED PERSON #2: Welcome.
We're excited to have you joining us today.
Fourteen-year-old Evelyn, Carmen's younger sister, logs in for an orientation session with her new online high school.
UNIDENTIFIED PERSON #2: Plan your term meaning.
Find your rhythm and adjust as needed, and then thrive.
Several months ago, the Schentrup family moved across the country, trading the palm trees of southern Florida for snowy mountain views outside Seattle.
They moved mostly for Philip's job.
He works for a tech company based here.
But there's more to it.

Evelyn, who shares her older sister's soulful eyes and glossy dark hair, tells me even though she really didn't want to move, hated leaving her Parkland friends behind, her parents needed a fresh start.
I think it was just hard for them being, like, around so many reminders of her.
Just needed to be away?
Yeah.
They need to be away from all the problems and the stress behind everything.
But when Evelyn started at her new high school in Washington, she had a couple of panic attacks.
That's why she's doing online classes.
I guess it was just too much change for me.
I just started crying out of nowhere.
And so I went to the bathroom to, like, wipe off my tears, you know, fix my makeup, like a teenager would do.
And then I couldn't stop crying.
It was just, like, a river of tears down my face.
Called my mom, and then...
And she called me, just saying, I can't breathe.
I can't.
I just can't be here.
